column14:
Three phase plan:

Phase 1 (Red) stay at home: This was the stay at home order phase. People could only leave the house for essential activities. 

Phase 2 (Yellow) safer at home: People can leave the house and businesses can begin to reopen, but people are encouraged to stay at home as much as possible. 

Phase 3 (Green) safer apart: This is the end goal. The state has yet to release specific details on this phase.

column14:
Four stage plan within stay-at home order:

Stage 1- Safety and Prepardness: Everything is under lockdown in this stage

Stage 2- Lower-Risk Workplaces: where retail (curbside and delivery only), related logistics and manufacturing, office workplaces, limited personal services, outdoor museums, child care, and essential businesses can open with modifications. The state is issuing guidance to help these workplaces reopen safely.

Stage 3- Higher-Risk Workplaces can begin to open. 

Stage 4- End of Stay at Home Order

column14:
There is a four phase plan to reopen: 

Phase 0: Stay at home. People were asked to stay at home aside from essential activities

Phase 1: Restaurants cannot excede 50% capacity and must implement social distancing, Bars, nightclubs, and pubs that derive 50% of sales from alcohol remain closed. Beaches still under the same restrictions and some state parks can open. Athletic facilities can open at 50% capacity. People should still not gather in more than 10 people. 

Phase 2: Should limit social gatherings to no more than 50 people. Individuals may resume non essential travel. Bars, pubs, and nightclubs can open at 50% capacity. Restaurants, personal services, and athletic facilities can operate at 75% capacity with social distancing maintained. Recreation is fully open including beaches and state parks. Large entertainment events can operate at 50% capacity.

Phase 3: Should limit time in crowded areas. Bars, restaurants, athletic facilities, and personal services can all operate at full capacity with limited social distancing measures implemented.

column4: Entertainment, food and drink, houses of worshipl, education,  outdoor and recreation,  personal care, retail

Phase 2- reopening and recovery: gradual, sequenced reopening of normal activities

Phase 3- building economic resiliency: building a resilient economy with strong business and job growth.

column4: Retail, personal care, food and drink, entertainment, outdoor and recreation, houses of worship.

column13: Idaho was originally scheduled to open on April 15th, but the governor extended the order until April 30th. They are now in stage 2 of their reopening plan.
column14:
Five stage plan to reopen the economy. Idaho has assumed they will be able move from each stage every two weeks. 

Initial stage: All residents are under self quaratine excluding essential activities and work

Stage 1: Daycares and houses of worship were allowed to open in this phase under strict guidelines. Gathering in public should be avoided. This phase took place from May 1-15th. 

Stage 2: Gathering in groups of less than 10 individuals is allowed. Restaurants dining rooms, recreation facilities, and close contact services can all open if they follow strict guidelines. 

Stage 3: Gatherings of 10-50 people are allowed to occur. Non-essential travel can begin. Bars can open but nightclubs and other large venues remain closed. 

Stage 4: Nightclubs and large venues can open under limited occupancy protocols. Gatherings over 50 individuals can occur.

column4: Retail, personal care, food and drink, outdoor and recreation, houses of worship, entertainment
column5: Gatherings are limited to less than 10 people and individuals are asked to remain home. Most retail establishments were deemed nonessential. Outdoor activities, including walking, running, and biking were considered essential. State and National parks were not forced to close, but decided to close on their own five days before the Executive Order was released.
column8: After cases continued to surge, the Governor extended the stay at home order until May 1st. He tried to further extend the order to May 30th, but a judge ruled that the Governor could not do that, so stuff started opening May 1st.
column11: Retail, personal care, outdoor and recreation, food and drink

column14:
The governor has created a five phase plan to reopen Illinois. Plan can be found here. 

Phase 1: Strict stay at home order in place. Only essential businesses are open. 

Phase 2: Non essential retail can open for curbside pickup. Residents can begin enjoying more outdoor activities such as golf and swimming. 

Phase 3: Gatherings of 10 people are allowed. Manufacturing and personal care services can open with capacity restrictions. 

Phase 4: Gatherings of 50 or fewer people are allowed. Restaurants and bars reopen. Schools and child care may resume. 

Phase 5: Everything is fully open with safety precautions in place.

A second expansion was applied to the stay at home order, keeping it in effect until May 1st. Several of their manufacturing and industrial entities were not deemed essential, forcing them to close. Many of the government services, including the state Bureau of Motor Vehicles and Executive Branch services, were suspended during the shutdown.

column14:
Five stage reopening plan:

Stage 1- March 23- May 3: Everything was closed. This is when the lockdown began. No social gatherings were allowed. 

Stage 2- May 4- May 23: Houses of worship were allowed to begin holding services. Manufacturers that were previously shut down are allowed to open. Half of the state's Bureau for Motor Vehicle services are allowed to open along with Executive Branch services. Gatherings of less than 25 people are allowed. Essential travel restrictions are lifted. Personal services begin by appointment. Retail and commercial establishments can operate at 50% capacity. 

Stage 3- May 24- June 13: Retail stores ard malls can operate at 75% capacity. Athletic facilities can open with restrictions. Community pools may open. Day care facilities are encouraged to open. Groups of less than 100 individuals may take place. 

Stage 4- Beginning June 14: Office buildings open and retail can operate at full capacity. Restaurants can operate at 75% dine in capacity. Bars and nightclubs can operate at 50% capacity. Entertainment and tourist venues can open under restrictions. 

Stage 5- Beginning July 4: Gatherings of over 250 people may take place. Everything is open at full capacity.

column14:
The state has created 10 rules for businesses to reopen. The 10 rules are: continue telework where possible, phased return to work, on-site temperature/health checks, universal masks and any other necessary PPE, close common area, enforce social distancing, limit face-to-face meetings, sanitizer/hand wash stations, special accomodations, testing plan. 

Businesses must submit a plan to follow these ten rules for approval before they are allowed to open.

column5: Gatherings of more than 10 individuals were prohibited. One of the strictest guidelines for businesses to close. According to the Executive Order, "all businesses, organizations, establishments, and facilities that are not part of the critical infrastructure sectors identified by the U.S. Department of Homeland Security’s Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency" were asked to close. They allowed retail to remain open for delivery services, restaurants could offer curbside and takeout options. Businesses were also allowed to perform tasks to keep property, fulfill managerial duties such as payroll, or taking care of live animals. Out of state travel was prohibited. Manufacturing facilities were forced to close which was not what other states did.

column13: The Governor issued a statewide "Healthy at Home" order that eased many of the covid restrictions. Baltimore and the surrounding counties decided to stay shut down and open under their own plans. Houses of worship and retail stores were allowed to open to 50% capactiy. Manufacturing facilities were allowed to reopen. Barber shops and beauty salons could open for hair services only and at 50% capacity. Golf courses and driving ranges; outdoor archery and shooting ranges; marinas and watercraft rental businesses; campgrounds; and horse boarding and riding facilities were allowed to open to the public. Restaurants and bars were ordered to remain closed. Malls, fitness centers, theaters, and other entertainment venues were asked to remain closed.
column14:
Three stage plan based on allowable activities. Each stage gives activity examples but notes that it is not an exhaustive list. 

Low Risk: This is the first recovery stage where low risk activities can resume and the stay at home order will be suspended. The types of activities that can resume are: small shops and certain small businesses; Curbside pickup and drop-off for businesses; Elective medical and dental procedures at ambulatory, outpatient, and medical offices; Limited attendance outdoor religious gatherings; Recreational boating, fishing, golf, tennis, hiking, and hunting; Car washes; Limited outdoor gym and fitness classes; Outdoor work with appropriate distancing measures; Some personal services

Medium Risk: Expected to be the longest stage of recovery. Most businesses will come back online during this stage. Examples of changes that could be implemented in this stage are: Raising the cap on social gatherings; Indoor gyms and fitness classes; Childcare centers; Transit schedules begin returning to normal; Indoor religious gatherings; Restaurants and bars with restrictions; Elective and outpatient procedures at hospitals

High Risk: This stage is long term goals. No timeline is projected on when they can reach this stage. Example of changes in this stage include: Larger social gatherings; High-capacity bars and restaurants; Lessened restrictions on visits to nursing homes and hospitals; Entertainment venues; Larger religious gatherings

column14:
Four staged approach to reopening the economy. Each stage is expected to last three weeks. 

Phase One- Start: Limited industries resume operations with severe restrictions

Phase Two- Cautious: Additional industries resume operations with restrictions and capacity limitations

Phase Three- VIgilant: Additional industries resume operations with guidance

Phase Four- New Normal: Development of vaccines or treatments allow people to begin a "new normal"

column4: Retail, Industries (manufacturing, construction, auto), personal care, food and drink, outdoor and recreation, houses of worship, entertainment

Any activities that are not necessary to sustain or protect life were prohibited.
column8: The order was extended at least four times.
column11: Industries (manufacturing, auto, construction), retail, food and drink, outdoor and recreation.
column13: The initial stay-at-home order was set to expire on May 22nd, but was extended to June 12th. This extension will make Michigan one of the last states to lift stay at home restrictions. Although the directions are coming from the Governor of the state, most of the openings are taking place on a county basis. Manufacturing, auto, and retail throughout the state were given permission to open under strict guidelines. Restaurants and other businesses in certain counties will open on a regional basis beginning June 1st. A lot of the golf courses and marinas throughout the state were allowed to open.
column14:
Six stage plan to reopen the economy: 

Stage One- Uncontrolled growth of COVID: There is an increasing number of new cases every day that could overwhelm the state’s health systems.

Stage Two- Persistent Spread: Michigan continues to see high case levels, with concern about health system capacity.

Stage Three- Flattening: The epidemic is no longer increasing and the health system’s capacity is sufficient for current needs.

Stage Four- Improving: Cases, hospitalizations and deaths are clearly declining.

Stage Five- Containing: Case and death rates continue to decline, with outbreaks quickly contained

Stage Six- Post-Pandemic: Reaching this phase would mean that community spread is not expected to return because of sufficient community immunity and availability of treatment.

According to the Governor of Michigan, the state is currently in phase three of the reopening plan.

column14:
Four phase plan to open up the economy:

Phase One: Gatherings of ten or fewer people are allowed. Retail can open at 50% capacity. Restaurants can allow for delivery and takeout. Drive in events for outdoor entertainment. Houses of worship can open at 25% capacity. 

Phase Two: Will begin phase two on June 1st. Campgrounds can open. Organized youth sports and youth programming can begin. School buildings can open for hybrid, summer learning. Personal services can begin under appointment only mandates. 

Phase Three: Gyms and athletic facilities are allowed to open. Restaurants can offer outdoor dining. Pools may be able to open under a phased system. Restaurants can offer indoor dining. 

Phase Four: Increased capacity in retail, pools, other facilities, and restaurants.

column14:
Three stage plan:

Stage One: MAIN STREET AND RETAIL BUSINESSES, RESTAURANTS / BARS / BREWERIES / DISTILLERIES / CASINOS, GYMS / POOLS / HOT TUBS, and MOVIE THEATRES became operational with reduced capacity and strict physical distancing protocols. PLACES OF WORSHIP became operational with reduced capacity and strict physical distancing protocols between non-household members. OUTDOOR RECREATION encouraged with strict physical distancing between groups and frequent sanitation of open public facilities. SENIOR LIVING OR ASSISTED LIVING FACILITIES continue to prohibit visitors. Strict protocols regarding hygiene and protection are followed, including daily symptom screening of staff and preventing ill workers from working. ORGANIZED YOUTH ACTIVITES became operational with strict physical distancing protocols.

Stage Two: Gatherings up to 50 people are allowed. ALL BUSINESSES can remain operational and must adhere to physical distancing. RESTAURANTS / BARS / BREWERIES / DISTILLERIES / CASINOS, GYMS / POOLS / HOT TUBS, and MOVIE THEATRES remain in the same operational status as PHASE ONE, but with an increase in capacity from 50% to 75%. ORGANIZED YOUTH ACTIVITES remain operational and should avoid GATHERING in groups of more than 50 people in circumstances that do not readily allow for appropriate physical distancing. PLACES OF ASSEMBLY including live music venues and bowling alleys can become operational with reduced capacity and must adhere to physical distancing. Avoid GATHERING in groups of more than 50 people in circumstances that do not readily allow for appropriate physical distancing. Cancel gatherings of more than 50 people unless physical distancing can be maintained.

Stage Three: No limit on group size. Vulnerable populations can resume public interactions, but should practice physical distancing, and continue to take precautionary measures.

column5: There wasn't a stay at home order, but the Governor issued Directed Health Measures (DHM) that were functionally the same according to the Whitehouse. Restaurants and bars were required to stop offering dine in services and gatherings of more than 10 people were prohibited. Retail stores were allowed to remain open if social distancing guidelines were met. Elective medical or dental work was prohibited. No distinction between essential and non essential businesses was made; everything was assumed to be essential.

Phase Two: Everything can open with 50% capacity and social distancing measures implemented. Groups cannot exceed 25 people

column14:
Five stage plan to reopen the economy:

Stage 1: This was full lockdown with the stay at home order in place. 

Stage 2: Low risk activities were allowed to resume. 

Stage 3: Additional activities allowed to resume that can be easily safeguarded

Stage 4: Most activities allowed with significant safeguarding. 

Stage 5: New normal.

column14:
Three phase plan:

Phase 1: Stay At Home order remains in place, people can leave home for commercial activity. Those retailers and services will need to implement social distancing, cleaning and other protocols. Gatherings limited to no more than 10 people. Parks can open subject to gathering limits. Face coverings recommended in public. Restrictions remain in place for nursing homes and other congregate living settings. Encourage continued teleworking

Phase 2: At least 2-3 weeks after Phase 1. Lift Stay At Home order with strong encouragement for vulnerable populations to continue staying at home. Allow limited opening of restaurants, bars and other businesses that can follow strict safety protocols (reduced capacity). Allow gathering at houses of worship and entertainment venues at reduced capacity Increase in number of people allowed at gatherings. Open public playgrounds. Continue rigorous restrictions on nursing homes and congregate living settings

Phase 3: At least 4-6 weeks after Phase 2. Lessen restrictions for vulnerable populations with encouragement to continue practicing physical distancing. Allow increased capacity at restaurants, bars, other businesses, houses of worship and entertainment venues. Further increase the number of people allowed at gatherings. Continue rigorous restrictions on nursing homes and congregate care settings

column14:
Phased plan "Open Up and Recover Safely" offers sector-specific guidance and a phased approach to reopening:

phase 1 part 1 (April 24): personal care, state parks, outdoor recreation, and retail can open
phase 1 part 2 (May 1): dining, entertainment, sporting venues, gyms, places of worship, tattoo parlors can reopen with social distancing and sanitation protocols, bars remain closed
phase 2 (May 15): bars can operare with lowered capacity, funerals and weddings can resume, childrens nurseries at places of worship can reopen
phase 3 (June 1): unrestricted staffing of workplaces, summer camps reopen, still maintain limited visits to hospitals and senior care facilities

all phases require a 14 day period of "manageable level" of hospital and incident rates before moving forward

column14:
The "Back to Normal" plan allows local officials to determine their own opening routes, but their locality must meet the following criteria in order to initiate the plan: 
1) downward trajectory of ILI for 14 day period and a plan for all symptomatic people to be able to recieve a test. 
2) downward trajectory of documented cases for 14 day period 
3) hospitals can treat all patients without crisis care, have a testing program in place for workers, and an adequate supply of protective equipment 
4) state has the capacity to rapidly investigate and contain cases

as was the case with closure, reopening remains entirely up to the individual business or operating entity as per local guidance.

column14:
Color coded 4 phase reopening plan

red=high risk: extreme precautions, remote work, essential travel only, interactions of 10 or fewer people, schools closed, high-contact businesses encouraged not to operate

orange=moderate risk (May 1 most counties): as outlined in first reopening

yellow=low risk (May 17 most counties): dine-in allowed, rotating shifts for offices, retail open, entertainment open with limitations, industry/construction can operate in groups

green="new normal" risk: all businesses open, large groups allowed

Business closures were initially scheduled to remain in place through April 15, and teleworking to remain through May 15th.

column14:
"Stay Home Stay Safe" order was in effect until May 15th, and was replaced by a "Be Smart, Stay Safe" order through June 15th. The new order encourages general public mask use, allowed limited opening of lodging operations and outdoor recreation. 

The state followed a phased approach to reopening:
Phase 1 (april 17): small constructoin and manufacturing crews can resume, single-worker services can resume
Phase 2 (april 24): expanded industry opening, outdoor retail shopping operations and farmers markets can resume
Phase 3 (May 1): required mask use on public transit, further expansion of industry reopening
Phase 4 (May 4): restart of elective medical procedures
Phase 5 (May 6): expanded some outdoor recreation and social interactions
Phase 6 (May 13): allowed limited resumption of retail operations deemed non-essential
May 22: lodging facilities can resume limited operations

All restaurants and on-site alcohol establishments had to close to the public but could continue takeout and delivery. Essential retail included grocery, electronic retail, auto and home improvement, alcohol stores, banks, printing, and laundromats. Sanitation guidelines suggested for essential businesses, and given a 10-patron limit.

phase 1: social distancing, 10 person gathering max, limited restaurants, limited retail, limited k12 schools
